snippet: The court ruled that there was not enough time to educate voters and officials about the law, but that it might go into effect in 2013.
abstract: Federal court temporarily blocks South Carolina from enforcing its new voter photo ID law during the November 2012 elections, saying there is not enough time to educate voters and officials about it; court rules that state could put the law into effect in 2013, but only if election officials use an 'extremely broad interpretation' of a provision that will make exceptions for voters who lack photo ID cards.
lead_paragraph: The court ruled that there was not enough time to educate voters and officials about the law, but that it might go into effect in 2013.

headline.seo: Court Blocks South Carolina Voter ID Law, for Now
headline.main: Federal Court Blocks Voter ID Law in South Carolina, but Only for Now
headline.print_headline: Federal Court Blocks Voter ID Law in South Carolina, but Only for Now
